Detailed Description

The abstract base class for DB-backed model objects.

Project EmeRails - Codename Ocarina

© 2008 Claudio Procida http://www.emeraldion.it

Every object of a subclass of ActiveRecord are mapped 1:1 to records of a table in a relational Database. Naming conventions assume that if the ActiveRecord subclass is called MyProduct, database records are stored in a table called my_products. Conversely, if an object of another class is in a relation with your object, it is assumed that a foreign key called my_product_id exists in the other table. Of course this is overridable by setting explicitly $table_name and $foreign_key to a value of your choice.

Definition at line 23 of file base.php.

Member Function Documentation

ActiveRecord::ActiveRecord ( $  _values = NULL  ) 

Constructs and initializes an ActiveRecord object.

Due to the lack of a static class initialization method, the default constructor is in charge of gathering information about the bound table columns the first time an object is created. Subsequent creations will use the values stored in static class variables. Subclassers don't need to override the constructor. They can in turn override the init method in order to perform custom initialization.

Parameters:
values Column values to initialize the object.

ActiveRecord::init ( $  values  )  [protected]

Performs specialized initialization tasks.

Subclassers will use this method to perform custom initialization.

Note:
The default implementation simply does nothing.
Parameters:
values An array of column-value pairs to initialize the receiver.

Reimplemented in AbstractComment, BlockedIp, DiarioPingback, Outbound, and Visit.

Definition at line 135 of file base.php.

Referenced by ActiveRecord().

ActiveRecord::get_table_name (  )  [private]

Returns the name of the table bound to this class.

This method returns the name of the table which contains data for objects of this class. If the ActiveRecord subclass is called MyRecord, the table name will be my_records. Of course you can override this behavior by setting explicitly the value of $table_name in the declaration of your class.

Definition at line 147 of file base.php.

References class_name_to_table_name().

Referenced by ActiveRecord(), BlockedVisit::count_by_ip(), delete(), find_all(), find_by_id(), and save().

ActiveRecord::get_foreign_key_name (  )  [private]

Returns the name of the foreign key for this class.

This method returns the name of the column to lookup when considering relations with objects of this class. If the ActiveRecord subclass is called MyRecord, the foreign key name will be my_record_id. Of course you can override this behavior by setting explicitly the value of $foreign_key_name in the declaration of your class.

Definition at line 165 of file base.php.

References class_name_to_foreign_key().

Referenced by has_and_belongs_to_many(), has_many(), and has_one().

ActiveRecord::get_primary_key (  )  [private]

Returns the name of the primary key for this class.

This method returns the name of the primary key in the table bound to this class. By default, ActiveRecord considers as primary key a column named id. Of course you can override this behavior by setting explicitly the value of $primary_key in the declaration of your class.

ActiveRecord::find_by_query ( $  query  ) 

Returns an array of model objects by executing a custom SELECT query.

Finder methods

This is a powerful instance method to retrieve objects from the database with a custom query. You can, among other things, do LEFT JOIN queries here.

Parameters:
query The SELECT query to fetch objects.

Definition at line 332 of file base.php.

References $db, and $row.

ActiveRecord::find_all ( $  params = array()  ) 

Returns an array of model objects that satisfy the requirements expressed in the params argument.

This method lets you find all objects of this class that satisfy a custom set of requirements, which you can express by setting the following keys of the params argument:

  • where_clause You can express a custom SQL WHERE expression here (e.g. `date` < '2008-05-01')
  • order_by You can express a custom SQL ORDER BY expression here (e.g. `date` DESC)
  • limit You can express a custom limit for the returned results.
  • start You can express a custom start for the returned results.
    Parameters:
    params An array of parameters for the underlying SQL query.

ActiveRecord::find ( $  id,
$  classname = 'ActiveRecord' 
) [static]

Returns an object whose primary key value is id.

Due to limitations of PHP, a static method always apply to the superclass. We have to explicitly reference the name of the subclass in order to create the right object.

Parameters:
id The value of the primary key.
classname The name of the subclass to apply this static method to.

Definition at line 422 of file base.php.

ActiveRecord::find_by_id ( $  id  ) 

Populates an object with the values of the DB row whose primary key value is id.

This instance method populates the receiver object with the contents of the DB row whose primary key is id.

Parameters:
id The primary key of the desired DB row.
Returns:
This method returns TRUE if such row exists, FALSE otherwise.

Definition at line 437 of file base.php.

References $columns, $db, $values, and get_table_name().

ActiveRecord::save (  ) 

Requests the receiver to save its data in the bound table.

This method has two distinct effects. If called on an object fetched from the table, it performs an UPDATE SQL statement to update the table data to the new values. If called on an object created programmatically, it performs an INSERT SQL statement, and sets the object's primary key value to the value resulting by the insert.

Returns:
This method returns TRUE if the object has been saved successfully.

Definition at line 473 of file base.php.

References $columns, $db, $i, and get_table_name().

ActiveRecord::delete ( $  optimize = TRUE  ) 

Deletes an object's database counterpart.

This method performs a DELETE SQL statement on the table bound to the receiver's class, requesting the deletion of the object whose primary key is equal to the receiver's primary key value. If the object has been created programmatically and lacks a primary key value, this method has no effect.

Parameters:
bool cleanup Set to FALSE if you do not want the table to be optimized after deletion.

Definition at line 544 of file base.php.

References $db, and get_table_name().

ActiveRecord::relative_url (  )  [protected]

Provides a relative URL that will be used by the permalink public method.

Subclassers that wish to provide custom permalinks for objects should override this method. You should return the URL portion after the APPLICATION_ROOT part only.

Reimplemented in AbstractComment, Client, DiarioAuthor, DiarioComment, DiarioPingback, DiarioPost, Software, and SoftwareArtifact.

Definition at line 571 of file base.php.

Referenced by permalink().

ActiveRecord::permalink ( $  relative = TRUE  ) 

Provides a unique permalink URL for the receiver object.

Subclassers that wish to provide custom permalinks for objects should not override this method. Override the relative_url method instead.

Parameters:
relative TRUE if the permalink should not contain the protocol and domain part of the URL, FALSE if you want them.

Reimplemented in SoftwareComment, and SoftwarePingback.

ActiveRecord::_set_initialized ( $  classname,
$  initialized 
) [static, private]

Marks the class classname as initialized.

This method allows ActiveRecord to keep track of what subclasses have already been initialized by inspectioning the bound database table schema, whithout the need for a per-class initialization method.

Parameters:
classname The name of the class that should be marked as initialized
initialized TRUE if the class should be considered initialized, FALSE otherwise.

Definition at line 671 of file base.php.

ActiveRecord::$foreign_key_name [protected]

Used to create the name of foreign key column in tables that are in a relationship with the bound table.

foreign_key_name Set this attribute only when the foreign key that references objects of this class is not the canonical name (e.g. 'product' for class Product).
